basic_syntax.title: Basic Syntax & Program Structure
basic_syntax.definition: Java program entry point, compilation, packaging and basic language constructs.
interview_key_points: public static void main(String[] args) is program entry point
Packages, imports and class visibility (public, protected, default, private)

qa.q: What is the role of the JVM?
qa.a: JVM loads and executes bytecode, manages memory, and provides runtime services (GC, classloading, security).

qa.q: How do you compile and run a Java program?
qa.a: javac MyApp.java → produces MyApp.class; run with java MyApp.

basic_syntax.code_example: public class Hello { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello"); } }

jvm_jre_jdk.title: JVM / JRE / JDK
jvm_jre_jdk.definition: JVM executes bytecode; JRE contains JVM + runtime libraries; JDK includes JRE + developer tools (javac, javadoc).
interview_key_points: JDK contains tools for development, JRE is runtime only
Classloader hierarchy: bootstrap, platform, application (parent delegation)

qa.q: What's the difference between JDK, JRE and JVM?
qa.a: JVM executes bytecode; JRE = JVM + libraries; JDK = JRE + developer tools.

primitive_vs_reference.title: Primitive vs Reference Types
primitive_vs_reference.definition: Primitive types store raw values (int, boolean, etc.); reference types store pointers to objects (String, arrays, custom objects).
interview_key_points: Passing primitives vs references to methods (by value)

qa.q: Are objects passed by reference in Java?
qa.a: No — Java is pass-by-value. For objects, the reference is passed by value.

primitive_vs_reference.code_example:
int a = 5;
Integer b = a; // autoboxing

operators_control_flow.title: Operators & Control Flow
operators_control_flow.definition: Java includes arithmetic, relational, logical operators and control structures if/else, switch, loops (for, while).

qa.q: When to use switch vs if-else?
qa.a: Use switch for multiple discrete values (enums, ints, strings) for clarity and potential performance.

oop_principles.title: OOP Principles
oop_principles.definition: Encapsulation, Abstraction, Inheritance, and Polymorphism are the pillars of object-oriented design.
interview_key_points: Encapsulation: hide fields and expose behavior
Abstraction: model essential behavior via interfaces/abstract classes

qa.a: Overloading: same name, different params (compile-time). Overriding: same signature in subclass (runtime dispatch).
Subtypes must be substitutable for their base types without breaking behavior.

oop_principles.code_example: class Animal{ void sound(){} } class Dog extends Animal{ void sound(){ System.out.println("woof"); } }

classes_objects.title: Classes, Objects & Constructors
classes_objects.definition: Classes define fields and methods; constructors initialize objects; static fields belong to class, instance fields to object.
interview_key_points: Default constructor provided if none declared
this() for constructor chaining, super() to call parent constructor
Static initialization block runs once when class initialized

qa.a: A no-arg constructor automatically provided if no constructors are defined.
Calling another constructor in the same class via this(...) or parent via super(...).

classes_objects.code_example: public class Person { private String name; public Person(String name){ this.name = name; } public String getName(){ return name; } }

abstract_interface.title: Abstract Classes & Interfaces
abstract_interface.definition: Abstract classes can have state and implemented methods; interfaces define contracts (Java 8+ can have default/static methods).
interview_key_points: When to use abstract class vs interface
Default and static methods in interfaces (since Java 8)

qa.a: Interfaces can have public static final constants, but not instance fields.

abstract_interface.code_example:
interface Fly{ default void takeOff(){ System.out.println("taking off"); } }
abstract class Vehicle{ abstract void drive(); }

encapsulation.title: Encapsulation
encapsulation.definition: Restrict direct access to fields and expose controlled operations via methods.
encapsulation.code_example: public final class ImmutablePoint{ private final int x,y; public ImmutablePoint(int x,int y){this.x=x;this.y=y;} public int getX(){return x;} }

list_set_map.title: List, Set, Map
list_set_map.definition: Core collection interfaces: List (ordered, indexable), Set (unique), Map (key-value).
interview_key_points: ArrayList vs LinkedList — random access vs insertion cost
HashSet vs TreeSet — hashing vs ordering
HashMap internal structure and resize behaviour

qa.q: When to use LinkedList over ArrayList?
qa.a: LinkedList is useful when frequent insertions/removals in middle and iteration are needed; ArrayList is better for random access.
When load factor threshold (default 0.75) is exceeded, capacity doubles and entries are rehashed.

list_set_map.code_example:
List<String> a = new ArrayList<>(); a.add("x");
Map<String,Integer> m = new HashMap<>(); m.put("k",1);

concurrent_collections.title: Concurrent Collections
concurrent_collections.definition: Collections designed for multi-threaded access (ConcurrentHashMap, CopyOnWriteArrayList).

qa.q: Why use ConcurrentHashMap instead of synchronized HashMap?
qa.a: ConcurrentHashMap offers better concurrency and avoids locking the whole map for reads or segment-level locking (implementation differs by Java version).

try_catch_finally.title: try / catch / finally
try_catch_finally.definition: Mechanism to catch and handle exceptions; finally executes regardless of exceptions to release resources.

qa.a: A try construct that automatically closes resources implementing AutoCloseable at the end of block.

try_catch_finally.code_example: try (BufferedReader r = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("f"))){ String s = r.readLine(); } catch(IOException e){ e.printStackTrace(); }

custom_exceptions.title: Custom Exceptions
custom_exceptions.definition: Define domain-specific exceptions by extending Exception or RuntimeException.
interview_key_points: When to create checked vs unchecked custom exceptions

qa.q: Should custom exceptions extend Exception or RuntimeException?
qa.a: If callers are expected to handle the error, use checked Exception; for programming errors, use RuntimeException.

custom_exceptions.code_example: class MyAppException extends Exception{ public MyAppException(String msg){ super(msg); } }

thread_lifecycle.title: Thread lifecycle & creation
thread_lifecycle.definition: Threads can be created by extending Thread or implementing Runnable/Callable and executed via ExecutorService.
interview_key_points: Thread states: NEW, RUNNABLE, BLOCKED, WAITING, TIMED_WAITING, TERMINATED
Callable returns value and supports exceptions

qa.a: It manages thread lifecycle, pooling, and task scheduling more efficiently than creating raw threads.

synchronization.title: Synchronization & Locks
synchronization.definition: Mechanisms to coordinate access to shared state: synchronized, ReentrantLock, volatile, atomic classes.

qa.a: Volatile ensures visibility (reads see latest writes) but does not provide atomicity for compound actions.

synchronization.code_example:
synchronized(this){ // critical section }
ReentrantLock lock = new ReentrantLock(); lock.lock(); try{} finally{ lock.unlock(); }

deadlock.title: Deadlock & Livelock
deadlock.definition: Deadlock occurs when two or more threads wait indefinitely for locks held by each other; livelock when threads repeatedly change state without progress.
interview_key_points: Avoid nested locks or use timeout tryLock
Lock ordering and resource hierarchy prevent deadlock

qa.a: Acquire locks in a consistent order, use tryLock with timeout, or reduce lock granularity.

deadlock.code_example:
Object a = new Object(), b = new Object();
// thread1 synchronizes a then b; thread2 synchronizes b then a -> potential deadlock

memory_model.title: Java Memory Model (JMM)
memory_model.definition: Defines how threads interact through memory, visibility guarantees, and happens-before relationships.
interview_key_points: Safe publication ensures objects are visible to other threads correctly

qa.a: A set of rules that guarantee memory visibility and ordering between actions (reads/writes) across threads.

garbage_collection.title: Garbage Collection (GC)
garbage_collection.definition: Automatic memory reclamation. Multiple collectors trade off throughput vs latency (Serial, Parallel, CMS, G1, ZGC).
interview_key_points: Generational GC: young (eden + survivor) and old generations
Minor GC vs Full GC impact and tuning
Use GC logs and tools (jstat, jmap, jvisualvm) for diagnosis

qa.a: Promotion failures, explicit System.gc calls (advised against), or old generation fragmentation/thresholds.

generics_basics.title: Generics & Type Erasure
generics_basics.definition: Generics enable compile-time type checks. Java implements generics via type erasure — generic type information is not present at runtime.
interview_key_points: Wildcards: ?, ? extends T (producer), ? super T (consumer) — PECS rule
Cannot create arrays of parameterized types (new T[])
Type erasure implications for instanceof and reflection

qa.a: Producer Extends, Consumer Super — guideline for deciding wildcard usage.

generics_basics.code_example: List<? extends Number> nums = new ArrayList<Integer>();

lambdas_streams.title: Lambdas & Streams
lambdas_streams.definition: Functional programming features introduced in Java 8 enabling concise code and pipeline processing of collections.
interview_key_points: Stream operations: map, filter, reduce, collect
Parallel streams vs thread pools: benchmark for specific workloads

qa.a: When operations are CPU-bound, stateless, and the data size is large enough to justify parallel overhead; measure performance.

lambdas_streams.code_example:
List<String> list = Arrays.asList("a","bb","ccc");
long count = list.stream().filter(s -> s.length() > 1).count();

optional.title: Optional
optional.definition: Container to explicitly model optional (nullable) return values to reduce NullPointerExceptions and signal absence.
interview_key_points: Prefer Optional for return types, not for fields
Useful methods: map, flatMap, orElse, orElseGet, ifPresent

streams_files.title: Streams & File I/O
streams_files.definition: java.io provides streams for blocking I/O; java.nio provides buffers, channels, and selectors for scalable non-blocking I/O.
interview_key_points: NIO offers selectors and non-blocking channels for high-performance servers
Files API (java.nio.file.Files) simplifies common file operations

jdbc_basics.title: JDBC Basics
jdbc_basics.definition: Standard Java API for relational database access using drivers, connections, statements, and result sets.
interview_key_points: Use PreparedStatement to prevent SQL injection
Use connection pooling for performance (HikariCP, DBCP)

qa.a: To precompile SQL and safely bind parameters preventing SQL injection attacks.

java_serialization.title: Serializable & Externalizable
java_serialization.definition: Mechanisms to convert objects to byte streams. Serializable is marker-based; Externalizable gives full control over serialization.
interview_key_points: Security concerns with default Java serialization

qa.a: To control compatibility across versions of a serializable class; prevents InvalidClassException on mismatch.

java_serialization.code_example: class Person implements Serializable { private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L; private String name; }

common_patterns.title: Singleton, Factory, Strategy, Observer
common_patterns.definition: Well-known patterns to solve recurring design problems, focusing on separation of concerns, extensibility, and testability.
interview_key_points: Singleton with enum to avoid reflection/serialization issues
Factory to decouple creation logic from usage
Strategy to swap algorithms at runtime

qa.a: Enum singletons are simple, inherently serializable-safe, and avoid reflection pitfalls.

common_patterns.code_example: public enum Singleton { INSTANCE; public void doSomething(){} }

unit_testing.title: Unit Testing (JUnit) & Build Tools
unit_testing.definition: JUnit and testing frameworks for unit tests. Build tools like Maven/Gradle manage dependencies and build lifecycles.
interview_key_points: Write deterministic unit tests with mocks (Mockito)
Use Maven/Gradle for reproducible builds and dependency management

qa.a: A small, fast test verifying a single unit of code in isolation.

perf_tips.title: Performance Tips
perf_tips.definition: Common performance considerations: avoid unnecessary object creation, use StringBuilder for concatenation in loops, choose right data structures.
interview_key_points: Prefer StringBuilder for repeated concatenation in loops
Avoid excessive autoboxing/unboxing in hot paths
Use appropriate collection types for expected workloads

qa.a: String is immutable; StringBuilder is mutable and efficient for repeated concatenation.

perf_tips.code_example: StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(); for(String s: list) sb.append(s); String res = sb.toString();
perf_tips.example: Measure first; optimize hotspots guided by profiler data.

what_is_html.title: What is HTML?
what_is_html.definition: HTML is a markup language used to structure and display content on web pages using predefined tags.
interview_key_points: HTML is not a programming language
HTML defines structure of web pages

qa.a: HTML is a markup language because it only structures content using tags and does not support programming logic like loops or conditions.

tags_elements.title: Tags vs Elements
tags_elements.definition: An HTML tag is a keyword enclosed within angle brackets,Tags are used to define the start and end of an element.An HTML element consists of the opening tag, the content, and the closing tag.It represents the complete structure that appears on the web page.
tags_elements.code_example: self closing tags

qa.q: What is the difference between a tag and an element?
qa.a: A tag is a syntax, while an element includes tags and content together.

qa.q: What are self-closing (void) tags in HTML? Give examples.
qa.a: Self-closing tags (also called void elements) are HTML tags that do not have closing tags and do not contain any content.They perform a single, specific function in the web page.

block_inline.title: Block vs Inline Elements
block_inline.definition: Block-level elements start on a new line and take up the full width available.They can contain other block-level or inline elements.Inline elements do not start on a new line and only take up as much width as their content.They usually contain text or other inline elements.
interview_key_points: Block elements start on new line
Inline elements do not break line
CSS display property can change behavior

qa.a: div, p, h1

qa.q: What is the difference between <div> and <span>?
qa.a:
div is a block-level element. It starts on a new line, takes up the full width available, and can contain both block-level and inline elements.
 span is an inline element. It does not start on a new line and only takes up the width of its content. It is mainly used for styling or grouping inline content.

attributes.title: HTML Attributes
attributes.definition: HTML attributes provide additional information about an element.They are written inside the opening tag and usually come in name–value pairs.Attributes control the behavior, appearance, or identification of an element.

qa.q: What is the purpose of the id attribute?
qa.a: It uniquely identifies an element in an HTML document.

forms_inputs.title: Forms & Input Elements
forms_inputs.definition: HTML forms collect user input and submit data to a server.

qa.q: What is the difference between GET and POST?
qa.a: GET sends data in URL, POST sends data in request body.

semantic_tags.title: Semantic Tags
semantic_tags.definition: Semantic tags clearly describe their meaning to both browser and developer.

qa.a: It improves accessibility, readability, and SEO.

img_audio_video.title: Image, Audio, Video
img_audio_video.definition: HTML supports multimedia using img, audio, and video elements.

qa.q: Why is the alt attribute important?
qa.a: It improves accessibility and helps SEO.

doctype_meta.title: DOCTYPE & Meta Tags
doctype_meta.definition: DOCTYPE defines HTML version; meta tags provide metadata about the document.

qa.a: It tells the browser which HTML version to use and prevents quirks mode.

what_is_css.title: What is CSS?
what_is_css.definition: CSS is a style sheet language used to describe the presentation of HTML elements.

qa.a: To style and layout web pages separately from HTML structure.

types_of_css.title: Types of CSS
types_of_css.definition: CSS can be applied in three ways: inline, internal, and external.
interview_key_points: Internal CSS used for small pages

qa.a: External CSS is preferred for scalability and maintenance.

basic_selectors.title: Basic Selectors
basic_selectors.definition: Selectors target HTML elements to apply styles.

qa.q: Difference between class and id selector?
qa.a: Class can be reused; id must be unique.

pseudo_selectors.title: Pseudo Classes & Elements
pseudo_selectors.definition: Pseudo-classes define a special state; pseudo-elements style parts of elements.

qa.a: Pseudo-classes define states; pseudo-elements define parts.

box_model.title: CSS Box Model
box_model.definition: Every element is a box consisting of content, padding, border, and margin.

qa.a: Controls whether padding and border are included in width/height.

display_property.title: Display Property
display_property.definition: Controls how elements are displayed in layout.

qa.a: display:none removes element; visibility:hidden hides but keeps space.

position_property.title: Position Property
position_property.definition: Defines how an element is positioned in the document.

qa.a: Absolute positions relative to nearest positioned ancestor.

flexbox.title: Flexbox
flexbox.definition: Flexbox is a one-dimensional layout system.

qa.a: Flexbox is one-dimensional; Grid is two-dimensional.

grid.title: CSS Grid
grid.definition: Grid is a two-dimensional layout system.

qa.a: When layout requires rows and columns.

media_queries.title: Media Queries
media_queries.definition: Media queries adapt layouts to different screen sizes.

qa.a: Designing for small screens first, then scaling up.

specificity.title: CSS Specificity
specificity.definition: Determines which CSS rule is applied when multiple rules match.

qa.a: It breaks cascade and makes debugging difficult.
Transition requires trigger; animation runs automatically.

lexical_scope.title: Lexical Scope
lexical_scope.definition: Lexical scope means variable access is determined by where the code is written, not where it is executed.
interview_key_points: Inner functions can access outer variables
lexical_scope.code_example: function outer(){ let a=10; function inner(){ console.log(a); } inner(); }

qa.a: Scope determined by the position of code in source.

closures.title: Closures
closures.definition: A closure is a function that remembers variables from its lexical scope even after the outer function has executed.
interview_key_points: Can cause memory leaks if misused
closures.code_example: function counter(){ let c=0; return function(){ return ++c; } }

qa.a: They help preserve state and encapsulate data.

execution_context.title: Execution Context
execution_context.definition: Execution context is the environment in which JavaScript code is evaluated and executed.

qa.a: Memory allocation and hoisting.

call_stack.title: Call Stack
call_stack.definition: Call stack is a data structure that keeps track of function calls in JavaScript.
call_stack.code_example: function a(){ b(); } function b(){ console.log('hi'); } a();

qa.a: Infinite or deep recursive calls.

memory_heap.title: Memory Heap
memory_heap.definition: Memory heap is where objects, arrays, and functions are stored.

qa.a: In the memory heap.

garbage_collection.title: Garbage Collection
garbage_collection.definition: Garbage collection automatically removes unused objects from memory.

qa.a: When objects become unreachable.

event_loop.title: Event Loop
event_loop.definition: Event loop manages execution of synchronous and asynchronous code.
interview_key_points: Runs after call stack is empty

qa.q: Which runs first: promise or setTimeout?
qa.a: Promise (microtask).

promises.title: Promises
promises.definition: Promises represent the eventual completion or failure of an async operation.

qa.q: Why promises are better than callbacks?
qa.a: Cleaner chaining and error handling.

async_await.title: Async / Await
async_await.definition: Async/await is syntactic sugar over promises for writing cleaner async code.
async_await.code_example: async function load(){ const res=await fetch(url); }

qa.a: No, it is non-blocking.

timers.title: setTimeout & setInterval
timers.definition: Timers schedule code execution after a delay or at intervals.

qa.a: setInterval if not cleared.

higher_order_functions.title: Higher Order Functions
higher_order_functions.definition: Functions that take other functions as arguments or return functions.

qa.a: Yes, but it does not return a new array.

pure_functions.title: Pure Functions
pure_functions.definition: Pure functions always return the same output for the same input and have no side effects.

qa.a: Easy testing and debugging.

iife.title: IIFE
iife.definition: Immediately Invoked Function Expression executes immediately after definition.

qa.a: To create private scope.

prototype.title: Prototype
prototype.definition: Prototype allows objects to inherit properties and methods.

qa.a: Object.prototype.

classes.title: Classes & Inheritance
classes.definition: Classes provide syntax for object creation and inheritance.
classes.code_example: class A{} class B extends A{}

qa.q: What happens if super is not called?
qa.a: ReferenceError occurs.

encapsulation.title: Encapsulation
encapsulation.definition: Encapsulation hides internal data and exposes controlled access.

qa.q: Can private fields be accessed outside?
qa.a: No.

debounce.title: Debounce
debounce.definition: Delays function execution until the event stops firing.

qa.a: Debounce waits, throttle limits.

immutability.title: Immutability
immutability.definition: Immutability means not modifying existing data directly.

qa.a: Predictable state updates.

memory_leaks.title: Memory Leaks
memory_leaks.definition: Memory leaks occur when unused memory is not released.

qa.a: setInterval.

what_is_jquery.title: What is jQuery?
what_is_jquery.definition: jQuery is a fast, lightweight JavaScript library that simplifies DOM manipulation, event handling, animations, and AJAX.

qa.a: No, jQuery is a JavaScript library.

jquery_vs_js.title: JavaScript vs jQuery
jquery_vs_js.definition: JavaScript is a programming language, while jQuery is a library built on JavaScript to simplify common tasks.

selectors_intro.title: jQuery Selectors
selectors_intro.definition: jQuery selectors are used to select and access HTML elements from the DOM for manipulation.

types_of_selectors.title: Types of Selectors
types_of_selectors.definition: jQuery provides different selectors like element, id, class, attribute, and pseudo selectors.

document_ready.title: $(document).ready()
document_ready.definition: Executes jQuery code after the DOM is fully loaded.

qa.a: No, if script is placed at bottom of the page.

ready_vs_onload.title: document.ready vs window.onload
ready_vs_onload.definition: document.ready runs after DOM load, while window.onload waits for full page load including images.

event_handling.title: Event Handling
event_handling.definition: jQuery handles user interactions like click, keyup, and change using event methods.

on_vs_click.title: on() vs click()
on_vs_click.definition: click() handles only click events for existing elements, while on() supports multiple events and dynamic elements.
interview_key_points: click() works only on existing elements

event_delegation.title: Event Delegation
event_delegation.definition: Event delegation attaches a single event listener to a parent element to handle events of child elements using bubbling.

ajax_intro.title: What is AJAX?
ajax_intro.definition: AJAX allows asynchronous communication with the server without reloading the web page.

ajax_methods.title: AJAX Methods
ajax_methods.definition: jQuery provides multiple AJAX methods for server communication.

effects_intro.title: Effects
effects_intro.definition: jQuery effects provide animations and visual transitions for UI interaction.

method_chaining.title: Method Chaining
method_chaining.definition: Method chaining allows calling multiple jQuery methods on the same element in a single statement.

html_vs_text.title: html() vs text()
html_vs_text.definition: html() works with HTML content including tags, while text() handles plain text only.

jquery_popularity.title: Why jQuery is Less Popular Now
jquery_popularity.definition: jQuery is less popular due to modern frameworks offering better performance and scalability.

what_is_react.title: What is React?
what_is_react.definition: React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces using reusable components and a virtual DOM.

qa.q: Is React a framework or library?
qa.a: React is a library focused on building UI.

jsx.title: JSX
jsx.definition: JSX is a syntax extension that allows writing HTML-like code inside JavaScript.
interview_key_points: Must return a single parent element

qa.a: No, but it improves readability and developer experience.

functional_components.title: Functional Components
functional_components.definition: Functions that return JSX and represent UI elements.
interview_key_points: Uses hooks for state and lifecycle

qa.a: They are simpler, cleaner, and work well with hooks.

class_components.title: Class Components
class_components.definition: Components created using ES6 classes (older approach).
class_components.code_example: class App extends React.Component { render(){ return <div/> } }

props.title: Props
props.definition: Props are read-only data passed from parent to child components.

qa.a: No, props are immutable.

state.title: State
state.definition: State holds mutable data within a component.

qa.a: State is internal and mutable; props are external and immutable.

use_state.title: useState
use_state.definition: Hook to manage state in functional components.

use_effect.title: useEffect
use_effect.definition: Hook to perform side effects in components.

qa.q: What happens if dependency array is empty?
qa.a: Effect runs once after initial render.

lifecycle_methods.title: Lifecycle Methods
lifecycle_methods.definition: Methods that run at different phases of component life.

reconciliation.title: Reconciliation
reconciliation.definition: Process by which React updates the DOM efficiently.

qa.a: They help React identify elements efficiently.

react_router.title: React Router
react_router.definition: Library for routing in React applications.

memoization.title: Memoization
memoization.definition: Avoid unnecessary re-renders using memoization techniques.

qa.a: When passing functions to child components.

context_api.title: Context API
context_api.definition: Provides global state without prop drilling.
interview_key_points: Alternative to Redux for small apps

error_boundaries.title: Error Boundaries
error_boundaries.definition: Components that catch JavaScript errors in child components.

spring.title: Spring & Spring Boot – Complete Interview Coverage

what_is_spring.title: What is Spring Framework?
what_is_spring.definition: Spring is a lightweight, open-source Java framework used to build enterprise applications by providing Dependency Injection, AOP, and infrastructure support.

qa.a: To reduce boilerplate code and build loosely coupled, maintainable applications.

ioc.title: Inversion of Control (IoC)
ioc.definition: IoC is a principle where object creation and dependency management are handled by the Spring container instead of the programmer.

qa.a: It removes tight coupling between classes.

dependency_injection.title: Dependency Injection (DI)
dependency_injection.definition: DI is a design pattern where dependencies are injected into a class instead of being created by the class itself.

qa.a: Constructor, Setter, Field injection.

spring_container.title: Spring Container
spring_container.definition: Spring container creates, manages, and controls the lifecycle of beans.

qa.a: ApplicationContext provides more enterprise features.

bean_lifecycle.title: Spring Bean Lifecycle
bean_lifecycle.definition: Bean lifecycle defines the stages from bean creation to destruction.

qa.a: Using @PostConstruct and @PreDestroy.

bean_scopes.title: Bean Scopes
bean_scopes.definition: Bean scope defines how long a bean instance exists.

qa.a: Singleton.
Use @Qualifier or @Primary.

aop.title: Aspect Oriented Programming (AOP)
aop.definition: AOP separates cross-cutting concerns from business logic.

qa.a: Logging, transactions, security.

what_is_mvc.title: What is Spring MVC?
what_is_mvc.definition: Spring MVC is a web framework based on the Model-View-Controller design pattern.

qa.a: Acts as front controller.
@RestController returns JSON directly.

what_is_spring_boot.title: What is Spring Boot?
what_is_spring_boot.definition: Spring Boot simplifies Spring application development using auto-configuration and embedded servers.

qa.a: Faster development with minimal configuration.

spring_vs_spring_boot.title: Spring vs Spring Boot
spring_vs_spring_boot.definition: Spring Boot reduces configuration compared to traditional Spring.

qa.q: Is Spring Boot replacement for Spring?
qa.a: No, it is built on top of Spring.

configuration.title: Spring Boot Configuration
configuration.definition: Spring Boot uses application.properties or application.yml for configuration.

qa.a: Using Spring Profiles.

transaction_management.title: Transaction Management
transaction_management.definition: Spring Boot supports declarative transaction management using @Transactional.

qa.a: Rollback on RuntimeException.

spring_security.title: Spring Security Basics
spring_security.definition: Spring Security handles authentication and authorization.

qa.a: Auth verifies user, Authorization verifies access.
